Description: If your source provides additional information worth preserving, either keep it with the original field names or create the dynamic **AdditionalFields** field, and add to it the extra information as key/value pairs.
OriginalDescription: If your source provides additional information worth preserving, either keep it with the original field names or create the dynamic **AdditionalFields** field, and add to it the extra information as key/value pairs.

Description: Alias or friendly name for `EventMessage` field.
OriginalDescription: Alias or friendly name for `EventMessage` field.

Description: Alias or friendly name for `EventUid` field.
OriginalDescription: Alias or friendly name for `EventUid` field.

Description: Title or name of the alert.
Example: Possible use of the Rubeus kerberoasting tool
OriginalDescription:
Title or name of the alert.
e.g. `Possible use of the Rubeus kerberoasting tool`

Description: The status of the alert as reported by the originating system.
OriginalDescription: The status of the alert as reported by the originating system.

Description:
Indicates the current state or progress of the alert.

Supported values are:
- `Active`
- `Closed`
OriginalDescription:
Indicates the current state or progress of the alert.

Supported values are:
- `Active`
- `Closed`

Description:
The final determination or outcome of the alert, indicating whether the alert was confirmed as a threat, deemed suspicious, or resolved as a false positive.

Supported values are:
- `True Positive` (Confirmed as a legitimate threat)
- `False Positive` (Incorrectly identified as a threat)
- `Benign Positive` (when event is determined to be harmless)
- `Unknown` (Uncertain or undetermined status)
OriginalDescription:
The final determination or outcome of the alert, indicating whether the alert was confirmed as a threat, deemed suspicious, or resolved as a false positive.

Supported values are:
- `True Positive` (Confirmed as a legitimate threat)
- `False Positive` (Incorrectly identified as a threat)
- `Benign Positive` (when event is determined to be harmless)
- `Unknown` (Uncertain or undetermined status)

Description: Recommended actions or steps to mitigate or remediate the identified attack or threat.
Example: 1. Make sure the machine is completely updated and all your software has the latest patch., 2. Contact your incident response team.
OriginalDescription:
Recommended actions or steps to mitigate or remediate the identified attack or threat.
e.g.
`1. Make sure the machine is completely updated and all your software has the latest patch.`
`2. Contact your incident response team.`

Description:
The attack tactics (name, ID, or both) associated with the alert.
Preferred format:
OriginalDescription:
The attack tactics (name, ID, or both) associated with the alert.
Preferred format:

e.g: `Persistence, Privilege Escalation`

Description:
The attack techniques (name, ID, or both) associated with the alert.
Preferred format:
OriginalDescription:
The attack techniques (name, ID, or both) associated with the alert.
Preferred format:

e.g: `Local Groups (T1069.001), Domain Groups (T1069.002)`

Description:
Provides detailed information about the specific detection method, technology, or data source that contributed to the generation of the alert. This field offers greater insight into how the alert was detected or triggered, aiding in the understanding of the detection context and reliability.

Supported values include:
- `EDR`: Endpoint Detection and Response systems that monitor and analyze endpoint activities to identify threats.
- `Behavioral Analytics`: Techniques that detect abnormal patterns in user, device, or system behavior.
- `Reputation`: Threat detection based on the reputation of IP addresses, domains, or files.
- `Threat Intelligence`: External or internal intelligence feeds providing data on known threats or adversary tactics.
- `Intrusion Detection`: Systems that monitor network traffic or activities for signs of intrusions or attacks.
- `Automated Investigation`: Automated systems that analyze and investigate alerts, reducing manual workload.
- `Antivirus`: Traditional antivirus engines that detect malware based on signatures and heuristics.
- `Data Loss Prevention`: Solutions focused on preventing unauthorized data transfers or leaks.
- `User Defined Blocked List`: Custom lists defined by users to block specific IPs, domains, or files.
- `Cloud Security Posture Management`: Tools that assess and manage security risks in cloud environments.
- `Cloud Application Security`: Solutions that secure cloud applications and data.
-`Scheduled Alerts`: Alerts generated based on predefined schedules or thresholds.
- `Other`: Any other detection method not covered by the above categories.
OriginalDescription:
Provides detailed information about the specific detection method, technology, or data source that contributed to the generation of the alert. This field offers greater insight into how the alert was detected or triggered, aiding in the understanding of the detection context and reliability.

Supported values include:
- `EDR`: Endpoint Detection and Response systems that monitor and analyze endpoint activities to identify threats.
- `Behavioral Analytics`: Techniques that detect abnormal patterns in user, device, or system behavior.
- `Reputation`: Threat detection based on the reputation of IP addresses, domains, or files.
- `Threat Intelligence`: External or internal intelligence feeds providing data on known threats or adversary tactics.
- `Intrusion Detection`: Systems that monitor network traffic or activities for signs of intrusions or attacks.
- `Automated Investigation`: Automated systems that analyze and investigate alerts, reducing manual workload.
- `Antivirus`: Traditional antivirus engines that detect malware based on signatures and heuristics.
- `Data Loss Prevention`: Solutions focused on preventing unauthorized data transfers or leaks.
- `User Defined Blocked List`: Custom lists defined by users to block specific IPs, domains, or files.
- `Cloud Security Posture Management`: Tools that assess and manage security risks in cloud environments.
- `Cloud Application Security`: Solutions that secure cloud applications and data.
-`Scheduled Alerts`: Alerts generated based on predefined schedules or thresholds.
- `Other`: Any other detection method not covered by the above categories.

Description: For reporting security systems, the action taken by the system, if applicable.
OriginalDescription:
For reporting security systems, the action taken by the system, if applicable.

Example: `Blocked`

OriginalDescription: A descriptive text associated with the device. For example: `Primary Domain Controller`.

Description: The type of  [DvcDomain](#dvcdomain). For a list of allowed values and further information, refer to [DomainType](normalization-entity-device.md#domaintype).

Description: The hostname of the device on which the event occurred or which reported the event, depending on the schema.
Note: This field supports both traditional FQDN format and Windows domain\hostname format. The  [DvcDomainType](#dvcdomaintype) field reflects the format used.
OriginalDescription:
The hostname of the device on which the event occurred or which reported the event, depending on the schema.

OriginalDescription:

Example: `41502da5-21b7-48ec-81c9-baeea8d7d669`

Description:
The type of [DvcId](#dvcid). For a list of allowed values and further information, refer to [DvcIdType](#dvcidtype).
- `MDEid`

If multiple IDs are available, use the first one from the list, and store the others by using the field names **DvcAzureResourceId** and **DvcMDEid**, respectively.
Note: This field is required if the [DvcId](#dvcid) field is used.
OriginalDescription:
The type of [DvcId](#dvcid). For a list of allowed values and further information, refer to [DvcIdType](#dvcidtype).

**Note**: This field is required if the [DvcId](#dvcid) field is used.

Description:
The number of events described by the record.

This value is used when the source supports aggregation, and a single record might represent multiple events.

For other sources, set to `1`.
OriginalDescription:
The number of events described by the record.

This value is used when the source supports aggregation, and a single record might represent multiple events.

OriginalDescription: The time in which the event ended. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the last event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.

OriginalDescription: The original severity as provided by the reporting device. This value is used to derive [EventSeverity](#eventseverity).

OriginalDescription:
The original event subtype or ID, if provided by the source. For example, this field is used to store the original Windows logon type. This value is used to derive [EventSubType](#eventsubtype), which should have only one of the values documented for each schema.

OriginalDescription: The owner of the event, which is usually the department or subsidiary in which it was generated.

OriginalDescription:

OriginalDescription: A URL provided in the event for a resource that provides more information about the event.

Description:
One of the following values: **Success**, **Partial**, **Failure**, **NA** (Not Applicable).

The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Alternatively, the source might provide only the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which should be analyzed to derive the EventResult value.
OriginalDescription:
One of the following values: **Success**, **Partial**, **Failure**, **NA** (Not Applicable).

The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Alternatively, the source might provide only the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which should be analyzed to derive the EventResult value.

Example: `Success`

OriginalDescription: The version of the schema. The version of the schema documented here is `0.1`.

OriginalDescription: The severity of the event. Valid values are: `Informational`, `Low`, `Medium`, or `High`.

OriginalDescription: The time in which the event started. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the first event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.

Description:
Specifies the subtype or category of the alert event, providing more granular detail within the broader event classification. This field helps distinguish the nature of the detected issue, improving incident prioritization and response strategies.

Supported values include:
- `Threat` (Represents a confirmed or highly likely malicious activity that could compromise the system or network)
- `Suspicious Activity` (Flags behavior or events that appear unusual or suspicious, though not yet confirmed as malicious)
- `Anomaly` (Identifies deviations from normal patterns that could indicate a potential security risk or operational issue)
- `Compliance Violation` (Highlights activities that breach regulatory, policy, or compliance standards)
OriginalDescription:
Specifies the subtype or category of the alert event, providing more granular detail within the broader event classification. This field helps distinguish the nature of the detected issue, improving incident prioritization and response strategies.

Supported values include:
- `Threat` (Represents a confirmed or highly likely malicious activity that could compromise the system or network)
- `Suspicious Activity` (Flags behavior or events that appear unusual or suspicious, though not yet confirmed as malicious)
- `Anomaly` (Identifies deviations from normal patterns that could indicate a potential security risk or operational issue)
- `Compliance Violation` (Highlights activities that breach regulatory, policy, or compliance standards)

Type of the event.

Supported values are:
-`Alert`
OriginalDescription:
Type of the event.

Supported values are:

Description:

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.
OriginalDescription:

Description:
Describes the operation audited by the event using a normalized value. Use [EventSubType](#eventsubtype) to provide further details, which the normalized value does not convey, and [Operation](#operation). to store the operation as reported by the reporting device.

For Audit Event records, the allowed values are:
- `Set`
- `Read`
- `Create`
- `Delete`
- `Execute`
- `Install`
- `Clear`
- `Enable`
- `Disable`
- `Initialize`
- `Start`
- `Stop`
- `Other`

Audit events represent a large variety of operations, and the `Other` value enables mapping operations that have no corresponding `EventType`. However, the use of `Other` limits the usability of the event and should be avoided if possible.
OriginalDescription:
Describes the operation audited by the event using a normalized value. Use [EventSubType](#eventsubtype) to provide further details, which the normalized value does not convey, and [Operation](#operation). to store the operation as reported by the reporting device.

- `Delete`

- `Stop`
- `Other`

Description:
The details associated with the event result. This field is typically populated when the result is a failure.

Allowed values include:
- `No such user or password`. This value should be used also when the original event reports that there is no such user, without reference to a password.
- `No such user`
- `Incorrect password`
- `Incorrect key`
- `Account expired`
- `Password expired`
- `User locked`
- `User disabled`
- `Logon violates policy`. This value should be used when the original event reports, for
Example: MFA required, log on outside of working hours, conditional access restrictions, or too frequent attempts., - Session expired, - Other, , The value may be provided in the source record using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. The original value should be stored in the field [EventOriginalResultDetails](normalization-common-fields.md#eventoriginalresultdetails)
OriginalDescription:
The details associated with the event result. This field is typically populated when the result is a failure.

Allowed values include:
- `No such user or password`. This value should be used also when the original event reports that there is no such user, without reference to a password.
- `No such user`
- `Incorrect password`
- `Incorrect key`
- `Account expired`
- `Password expired`
- `User locked`
- `User disabled`
- `Logon violates policy`. This value should be used when the original event reports, for example: MFA required, log on outside of working hours, conditional access restrictions, or too frequent attempts.
- `Session expired`
- `Other`

The value may be provided in the source record using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. The original value should be stored in the field [EventOriginalResultDetails](normalization-common-fields.md#eventoriginalresultdetails)

Description:

- `System`
- `Interactive`
- `RemoteInteractive`
- `Service`
- `RemoteService`
- `Remote` - Use when the type of remote sign-in is unknown.
- `AssumeRole` - Typically used when the event type is `Elevate`.

The value may be provided in the source record using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. The original value should be stored in the field [EventOriginalSubType](normalization-common-fields.md#eventoriginalsubtype).
OriginalDescription:

Specifies the type of the user name stored in the [SrcUsername](#srcusername) field. For more information, and list of allowed values, see [UsernameType](normalization-entity-user.md#usernametype) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

Example: `Windows`

Description:
The category of the threat or malware identified in the alert.

Supported values are: `Malware`, `Ransomware`, `Trojan`, `Virus`, `Worm`, `Adware`, `Spyware`, `Rootkit`, `Cryptominor`, `Phishing`, `Spam`, `MaliciousUrl`, `Spoofing`, `Security Policy Violation`, `Unknown`
OriginalDescription:
The category of the threat or malware identified in the alert.

Supported values are: `Malware`, `Ransomware`, `Trojan`, `Virus`, `Worm`, `Adware`, `Spyware`, `Rootkit`, `Cryptominor`, `Phishing`, `Spam`, `MaliciousUrl`, `Spoofing`, `Security Policy Violation`, `Unknown`

Description: The confidence level of the threat identified, normalized to a value between 0 and a 100.
OriginalDescription: The confidence level of the threat identified, normalized to a value between 0 and a 100.

Description: Date and time when the threat was first reported.
OriginalDescription:
Date and time when the threat was first reported.

e.g. `2024-09-19T10:12:10.0000000Z`

OriginalDescription:
The ID of the threat or malware identified in the alert.

e.g. `1234567891011121314`

Description:
Indicates whether the threat is currently active.

Supported values are: `True`, `False`
OriginalDescription:
Indicates whether the threat is currently active.

Supported values are: `True`, `False`

OriginalDescription:
Date and time when the threat was last reported.

e.g. `2024-09-19T10:12:10.0000000Z`

Description: The name of the threat or malware identified in the alert.
OriginalDescription:
The name of the threat or malware identified in the alert.

e.g. `Init.exe`

Description: The confidence level as reported by the originating system.
OriginalDescription: The confidence level as reported by the originating system.

Description: The risk level as reported by the originating system.
OriginalDescription: The risk level as reported by the originating system.

Description:
The risk level associated with the threat. The level should be a number between 0 and 100.

Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using a different scale, which should be normalized to this scale. The original value should be stored in ThreatRiskLevelOriginal.
OriginalDescription:
The risk level associated with the threat. The level should be a number between 0 and 100.

Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using a different scale, which should be normalized to this scale. The original value should be stored in ThreatRiskLevelOriginal.

Description: The time the event was generated by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription: The time the event was generated by the reporting device.

Description:
The original table from which the record was fetched. This field is useful when the same event can be received through multiple channels to different tables, and have the same [EventVendor](#eventvendor) and [EventProduct](#eventproduct) values.

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.
OriginalDescription:
The original table from which the record was fetched. This field is useful when the same event can be received through multiple channels to different tables, and have the same [EventVendor](#eventvendor) and [EventProduct](#eventproduct) values.

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.

Description: Alias for [SrcUsername](#srcusername)
OriginalDescription: Alias for [SrcUsername](#srcusername)

Description: If your source provides additional information worth preserving, either keep it with the original field names or create the dynamic **AdditionalFields** field, and add to it the extra information as key/value pairs.
OriginalDescription: If your source provides additional information worth preserving, either keep it with the original field names or create the dynamic **AdditionalFields** field, and add to it the extra information as key/value pairs.

Description:
The flags field, as provided by the reporting device. If flag information is provided in multiple fields, concatenate them with comma as a separator.

Since DNS flags are complex to parse and are less often used by analytics, parsing, and normalization aren't required. Microsoft Sentinel can use an auxiliary function to provide flags information. For more information, see [Handling DNS response](#handling-dns-response).
OriginalDescription:
The flags field, as provided by the reporting device. If flag information is provided in multiple fields, concatenate them with comma as a separator.

Since DNS flags are complex to parse and are less often used by analytics, parsing, and normalization aren't required. Microsoft Sentinel can use an auxiliary function to provide flags information. For more information, see [Handling DNS response](#handling-dns-response).

Example: `["DR"]`

Description: The DNS `AD` flag, which is related to DNSSEC, indicates in a response that all data included in the answer and authority sections of the response have been verified by the server according to the policies of that server. For more information, see [RFC 3655 Section 6.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3655#section-6.1) for more information.
OriginalDescription: The DNS `AD` flag, which is related to DNSSEC, indicates in a response that all data included in the answer and authority sections of the response have been verified by the server according to the policies of that server. For more information, see [RFC 3655 Section 6.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3655#section-6.1) for more information.

Description: The DNS `AA` flag indicates whether the response from the server was authoritative
OriginalDescription: The DNS `AA` flag indicates whether the response from the server was authoritative

Description: The DNS `CD` flag, which is related to DNSSEC, indicates in a query that non-verified data is acceptable to the system sending the query. For more information, see [RFC 3655 Section 6.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3655#section-6.1) for more information.
OriginalDescription: The DNS `CD` flag, which is related to DNSSEC, indicates in a query that non-verified data is acceptable to the system sending the query. For more information, see [RFC 3655 Section 6.1](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3655#section-6.1) for more information.

Description: The DNS `RA` flag indicates in a response that  that server supports recursive queries.
OriginalDescription: The DNS `RA` flag indicates in a response that  that server supports recursive queries.

Description: The DNS `RD` flag indicates in a request that that client would like the server to use recursive queries.
OriginalDescription: The DNS `RD` flag indicates in a request that that client would like the server to use recursive queries.

Description: The DNS `TC` flag indicates that a response was truncated as it exceeded the maximum response size.
OriginalDescription: The DNS `TC` flag indicates that a response was truncated as it exceeded the maximum response size.

Description: The DNS `Z` flag is a deprecated DNS flag, which might be reported by older DNS systems.
OriginalDescription: The DNS `Z` flag is a deprecated DNS flag, which might be reported by older DNS systems.

Description: The amount of time, in milliseconds, for the completion of DNS request.
OriginalDescription:
The amount of time, in milliseconds, for the completion of DNS request.

Example: `1500`

Description:
The domain that the request tries to resolve.

**Notes**:
- Some sources send valid FQDN queries in a different format. For example, in the DNS protocol itself, the query includes a dot (**.**) at the end, which must be removed.
- While the DNS protocol limits the type of value in this field to an FQDN, most DNS servers allow any value, and this field is therefore not limited to FQDN values only. Most notably, DNS tunneling attacks may use invalid FQDN values in the query field.
- While the DNS protocol allows for multiple queries in a single request, this scenario is rare, if it's found at all. If the request has multiple queries, store the first one in this field, and then and optionally keep the rest in the [AdditionalFields](normalization-common-fields.md#additionalfields) field.
OriginalDescription:
The domain that the request tries to resolve.

**Notes**:
- Some sources send valid FQDN queries in a different format. For example, in the DNS protocol itself, the query includes a dot (**.**) at the end, which must be removed.
- While the DNS protocol limits the type of value in this field to an FQDN, most DNS servers allow any value, and this field is therefore not limited to FQDN values only. Most notably, DNS tunneling attacks may use invalid FQDN values in the query field.
- While the DNS protocol allows for multiple queries in a single request, this scenario is rare, if it's found at all. If the request has multiple queries, store the first one in this field, and then and optionally keep the rest in the [AdditionalFields](normalization-common-fields.md#additionalfields) field.

Example: `www.malicious.com`

Description:
The [DNS class ID](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).

In practice, only the **IN** class (ID 1) is used, and therefore this field is less valuable.
OriginalDescription:
The [DNS class ID](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).

In practice, only the **IN** class (ID 1) is used, and therefore this field is less valuable.

Description: The [DNS Resource Record Type codes](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).
OriginalDescription:
The [DNS Resource Record Type codes](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).

Example: `28`

Description:
The [DNS Resource Record Type](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml) names.

**Notes**:
- IANA doesn't define the case for the values, so analytics must normalize the case as needed.
- The value `ANY` is supported for the response code 255.
- The value `TYPExxxx` is supported for unmapped response codes, where `xxxx` is the numerical value of the response code, as reported by the BIND DNS server.
-If the source provides only a numerical query type code and not a query type name, the parser must include a lookup table to enrich with this value.
OriginalDescription:
The [DNS Resource Record Type](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml) names.

**Notes**:
- IANA doesn't define the case for the values, so analytics must normalize the case as needed.
- The value `ANY` is supported for the response code 255.
- The value `TYPExxxx` is supported for unmapped response codes, where `xxxx` is the numerical value of the response code, as reported by the BIND DNS server.
-If the source provides only a numerical query type code and not a query type name, the parser must include a lookup table to enrich with this value.

Example: `AAAA`

Description: The [DNS numerical response code](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).
OriginalDescription:

Description:
The content of the response, as included in the record.

The DNS response data is inconsistent across reporting devices, is complex to parse, and has less value for source-agnostic analytics. For more information, see [Handling DNS response](#handling-dns-response).

Example: `69f37748-ddcd-4331-bf0f-b137f1ea83b`

Description: The owner of the event, which is usually the department or subsidiary in which it was generated.
OriginalDescription: The owner of the event, which is usually the department or subsidiary in which it was generated.

Description: The product generating the event. The value should be one of the values listed in [Vendors and Products](#vendors-and-products).
OriginalDescription:
The product generating the event. The value should be one of the values listed in [Vendors and Products](#vendors-and-products).

Example: `Sysmon`

OriginalDescription:
The version of the product generating the event.

Example: `12.1`

Description: A URL provided in the event for a resource that provides more information about the event.
OriginalDescription: A URL provided in the event for a resource that provides more information about the event.

Description:
One of the following values: **Success**, **Partial**, **Failure**, **NA** (Not Applicable).

The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Alternatively, the source might provide only the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which should be analyzed to derive the EventResult value.
OriginalDescription:
One of the following values: **Success**, **Partial**, **Failure**, **NA** (Not Applicable).

The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Alternatively, the source might provide only the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which should be analyzed to derive the EventResult value.

Example: `Success`

Description:
For DNS events, this field provides the [DNS response code](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).

**Notes**:
- IANA doesn't define the case for the values, so analytics must normalize the case.
- If the source provides only a numerical response code and not a response code name, the parser must include a lookup table to enrich with this value.
- If this record represents a request and not a response, set to **NA**.
OriginalDescription:
For DNS events, this field provides the [DNS response code](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).

**Notes**:
- IANA doesn't define the case for the values, so analytics must normalize the case.
- If the source provides only a numerical response code and not a response code name, the parser must include a lookup table to enrich with this value.
- If this record represents a request and not a response, set to **NA**.

Example: `NXDOMAIN`

Description: The name of the schema documented here is **Dns**.
OriginalDescription: The name of the schema documented here is **Dns**.

Description: The version of the schema documented here is **0.1.7**.
OriginalDescription: The version of the schema documented here is **0.1.7**.

Description: The severity of the event. Valid values are: `Informational`, `Low`, `Medium`, or `High`.
OriginalDescription: The severity of the event. Valid values are: `Informational`, `Low`, `Medium`, or `High`.

Description: The time in which the event started. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the first event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.
OriginalDescription: The time in which the event started. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the first event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.

Description:
Either `request` or `response`.

For most sources, [only the responses are logged](#guidelines-for-collecting-dns-events), and therefore the value is often **response**.
OriginalDescription:
Either `request` or `response`.

For most sources, [only the responses are logged](#guidelines-for-collecting-dns-events), and therefore the value is often **response**.

Description:
Indicates the operation reported by the record.

For DNS records, this value would be the [DNS op code](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).
OriginalDescription:
Indicates the operation reported by the record.

For DNS records, this value would be the [DNS op code](https://www.iana.org/assignments/dns-parameters/dns-parameters.xhtml).

OriginalDescription: The unique ID of the record, as assigned by Microsoft Sentinel. This field is typically mapped to the `_ItemId` Log Analytics field.

For other sources, set to `1`.
OriginalDescription:

This value is used when the source supports aggregation, and a single record might represent multiple events.

OriginalDescription: The time in which the event ended. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the last event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.

Description:
One of the following values: **Success**, **Partial**, **Failure**, **NA** (Not Applicable).

The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Alternatively, the source might provide only the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which should be analyzed to derive the EventResult value.

Description: The risk level associated with the identified threat. The level should be a number between **0** and **100**.
Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using a different scale, which should be normalized to this scale. The original value should be stored in [ThreatOriginalRiskLevel](#threatoriginalrisklevel).

The risk level associated with the identified threat. The level should be a number between **0** and **100**.

OriginalDescription: The time the event was generated by the reporting device.

Description:
The original table from which the record was fetched. This field is useful when the same event can be received through multiple channels to different tables, and have the same [EventVendor](#eventvendor) and [EventProduct](#eventproduct) values.

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.
OriginalDescription:
The original table from which the record was fetched. This field is useful when the same event can be received through multiple channels to different tables, and have the same [EventVendor](#eventvendor) and [EventProduct](#eventproduct) values.

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.

DocType: Use when the file path is available as a URL. URLs are not limited to *http* or *https*, and any value, including an FTP value, is valid.

OriginalDescription: Alias to [TargetUrl](#targeturl)

Description: Alias to the [ActorUsername](#actorusername) field.

Description: The process ID (PID) of the process that terminated the network session.
Note:
The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows and Linux this value must be numeric.

OriginalDescription:

Description:
The action taken on the network session. Supported values are:
- `Allow`
- `Deny`
- `Drop`
- `Drop ICMP`
- `Reset`
- `Reset Source`
- `Reset Destination`
- `Encrypt`
- `Decrypt`
- `VPNroute`
Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. The original value should be stored in the [DvcOriginalAction](normalization-common-fields.md#dvcoriginalaction) field.

OriginalDescription: A URL provided in the event for a resource that provides more information about the event.

Description:
If the source device does not provide an event result, **EventResult** should be based on the value of [DvcAction](#dvcaction). If [DvcAction](#dvcaction) is `Deny`, `Drop`, `Drop ICMP`, `Reset`, `Reset Source`, or `Reset Destination`
, **EventResult** should be `Failure`. Otherwise, **EventResult** should be `Success`.
OriginalDescription:
If the source device does not provide an event result, **EventResult** should be based on the value of [DvcAction](#dvcaction). If [DvcAction](#dvcaction) is `Deny`, `Drop`, `Drop ICMP`, `Reset`, `Reset Source`, or `Reset Destination`
, **EventResult** should be `Failure`. Otherwise, **EventResult** should be `Success`.

Description:
Reason or details for the result reported in the [EventResult](#eventresult) field. Supported values are:
- Failover
- Invalid TCP
- Invalid Tunnel
- Maximum Retry
- Reset
- Routing issue
- Simulation
- Terminated
- Timeout
- Transient error
- Unknown
- NA.

The original, source specific, value is stored in the [EventOriginalResultDetails](normalization-common-fields.md#eventoriginalresultdetails) field.
OriginalDescription:
Reason or details for the result reported in the [EventResult](#eventresult) field. Supported values are:
- Failover
- Invalid TCP
- Invalid Tunnel
- Maximum Retry
- Reset
- Routing issue
- Simulation
- Terminated
- Timeout
- Transient error
- Unknown
- NA.

The original, source specific, value is stored in the [EventOriginalResultDetails](normalization-common-fields.md#eventoriginalresultdetails) field.

Description: The name of the schema documented here is `NetworkSession`.
OriginalDescription: The name of the schema documented here is `NetworkSession`.

Description: The version of the schema. The version of the schema documented here is `0.2.7`.
OriginalDescription: The version of the schema. The version of the schema documented here is `0.2.7`.

Description:
If the source device does not provide an event severity, **EventSeverity** should be based on the value of [DvcAction](#dvcaction). If [DvcAction](#dvcaction) is `Deny`, `Drop`, `Drop ICMP`, `Reset`, `Reset Source`, or `Reset Destination`
, **EventSeverity** should be `Low`. Otherwise, **EventSeverity** should be `Informational`.
OriginalDescription:
If the source device does not provide an event severity, **EventSeverity** should be based on the value of [DvcAction](#dvcaction). If [DvcAction](#dvcaction) is `Deny`, `Drop`, `Drop ICMP`, `Reset`, `Reset Source`, or `Reset Destination`
, **EventSeverity** should be `Low`. Otherwise, **EventSeverity** should be `Informational`.

Description: The time in which the event started. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the first event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.
OriginalDescription: The time in which the event started. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the first event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.

Description:
Additional description of the event type, if applicable.
For Network Session records, supported values include:
- `Start`
- `End`

This is field is not relevant for `Flow` events.
OriginalDescription:
Additional description of the event type, if applicable.
For Network Session records, supported values include:
- `Start`
- `End`

This is field is not relevant for `Flow` events.

Description:
Describes the scenario reported by the record.

For Network Session records, the allowed values are:
- `EndpointNetworkSession`
- `NetworkSession`
- `L2NetworkSession`
- `IDS`
- `Flow`

For more information on event types, refer to the [schema overview](#schema-overview)
OriginalDescription:
Describes the scenario reported by the record.

For Network Session records, the allowed values are:
- `EndpointNetworkSession`
- `NetworkSession`
- `L2NetworkSession`
- `IDS`
- `Flow`

For more information on event types, refer to the [schema overview](#schema-overview)

Description: The unique ID of the record, as assigned by Microsoft Sentinel. This field is typically mapped to the `_ItemId` Log Analytics field.
OriginalDescription: The unique ID of the record, as assigned by Microsoft Sentinel. This field is typically mapped to the `_ItemId` Log Analytics field.

Description: The vendor of the product generating the event. The value should be one of the values listed in [Vendors and Products](#vendors-and-products).
OriginalDescription:
The vendor of the product generating the event. The value should be one of the values listed in [Vendors and Products](#vendors-and-products).

Example: `Microsoft`

Description:
- If the event type is `NetworkSession`, `Flow` or `L2NetworkSession`, Hostname is an alias to [DstHostname](#dsthostname).
- If the event type is `EndpointNetworkSession`, Hostname is an alias to `RemoteHostname`, which can alias either [DstHostname](#dsthostname) or [SrcHostName](#srchostname), depending on [NetworkDirection](#networkdirection)
OriginalDescription:
- If the event type is `NetworkSession`, `Flow` or `L2NetworkSession`, Hostname is an alias to [DstHostname](#dsthostname).
- If the event type is `EndpointNetworkSession`, Hostname is an alias to `RemoteHostname`, which can alias either [DstHostname](#dsthostname) or [SrcHostName](#srchostname), depending on [NetworkDirection](#networkdirection)

Description:
Alias to [SrcVlanId](#srcvlanid).

In many cases, the VLAN can't be determined as a source or a destination but is characterized as inner or outer. This alias to signifies that [SrcVlanId](#srcvlanid) should be used when the VLAN is characterized as inner.
OriginalDescription:
Alias to [SrcVlanId](#srcvlanid).

In many cases, the VLAN can't be determined as a source or a destination but is characterized as inner or outer. This alias to signifies that [SrcVlanId](#srcvlanid) should be used when the VLAN is characterized as inner.

Description:
- If the event type is `NetworkSession`, `Flow` or `L2NetworkSession`, IpAddr is an alias to [SrcIpAddr](#srcipaddr).
- If the event type is `EndpointNetworkSession`, IpAddr is an alias to `LocalIpAddr`, which can alias either [SrcIpAddr](#srcipaddr) or [DstIpAddr](#dstipaddr), depending on [NetworkDirection](#networkdirection).
OriginalDescription:
- If the event type is `NetworkSession`, `Flow` or `L2NetworkSession`, IpAddr is an alias to [SrcIpAddr](#srcipaddr).
- If the event type is `EndpointNetworkSession`, IpAddr is an alias to `LocalIpAddr`, which can alias either [SrcIpAddr](#srcipaddr) or [DstIpAddr](#dstipaddr), depending on [NetworkDirection](#networkdirection).

Description: The application layer protocol used by the connection or session. The value should be in all uppercase.
OriginalDescription:
The application layer protocol used by the connection or session. The value should be in all uppercase.

Example: `FTP`

Description: Number of bytes sent in both directions. If both **BytesReceived** and **BytesSent** exist, **BytesTotal** should equal their sum. If the event is aggregated, **NetworkBytes** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.
OriginalDescription:
Number of bytes sent in both directions. If both **BytesReceived** and **BytesSent** exist, **BytesTotal** should equal their sum. If the event is aggregated, **NetworkBytes** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.

Example: `78991`

Description: TCP flags and other potential IP header information.
OriginalDescription: TCP flags and other potential IP header information.

Description:
The direction of the connection or session:

- For the [EventType](#eventtype) `NetworkSession`, `Flow` or `L2NetworkSession`, **NetworkDirection** represents the direction relative to the organization or cloud environment boundary. Supported values are `Inbound`, `Outbound`, `Local` (to the organization), `External` (to the organization) or `NA` (Not Applicable).

- For the [EventType](#eventtype) `EndpointNetworkSession`, **NetworkDirection** represents the direction relative to the endpoint. Supported values are `Inbound`, `Outbound`, `Local` (to the system), `Listen` or `NA` (Not Applicable). The `Listen` value indicates that a device has started accepting network connections but isn't actually, necessarily, connected.
OriginalDescription:
The direction of the connection or session:

- For the [EventType](#eventtype) `NetworkSession`, `Flow` or `L2NetworkSession`, **NetworkDirection** represents the direction relative to the organization or cloud environment boundary. Supported values are `Inbound`, `Outbound`, `Local` (to the organization), `External` (to the organization) or `NA` (Not Applicable).

- For the [EventType](#eventtype) `EndpointNetworkSession`, **NetworkDirection** represents the direction relative to the endpoint. Supported values are `Inbound`, `Outbound`, `Local` (to the system), `Listen` or `NA` (Not Applicable). The `Listen` value indicates that a device has started accepting network connections but isn't actually, necessarily, connected.

Description: The amount of time, in milliseconds, for the completion of the network session or connection.
OriginalDescription:
The amount of time, in milliseconds, for the completion of the network session or connection.

Example: `1500`

Description: For an ICMP message, the ICMP code number as described in [RFC 2780](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2780) for IPv4 network connections, or in [RFC 4443](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4443) for IPv6 network connections.
OriginalDescription: For an ICMP message, the ICMP code number as described in [RFC 2780](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2780) for IPv4 network connections, or in [RFC 4443](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4443) for IPv6 network connections.

Description: For an ICMP message, ICMP type name associated with the numerical value, as described in [RFC 2780](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2780) for IPv4 network connections, or in [RFC 4443](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4443) for IPv6 network connections.
OriginalDescription:
For an ICMP message, ICMP type name associated with the numerical value, as described in [RFC 2780](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2780) for IPv4 network connections, or in [RFC 4443](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4443) for IPv6 network connections.

Example: `Destination Unreachable` for NetworkIcmpCode `3`

Description: The number of packets sent in both directions. If both **PacketsReceived** and **PacketsSent** exist, **PacketsTotal** should equal their sum. The meaning of a packet is defined by the reporting device. If the event is aggregated, **NetworkPackets** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.
OriginalDescription:
The number of packets sent in both directions. If both **PacketsReceived** and **PacketsSent** exist, **PacketsTotal** should equal their sum. The meaning of a packet is defined by the reporting device. If the event is aggregated, **NetworkPackets** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.

Example: `6924`

Description: The IP protocol used by the connection or session as listed in [IANA protocol assignment](https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml), which is typically `TCP`, `UDP`, or `ICMP`.
OriginalDescription:
The IP protocol used by the connection or session as listed in [IANA protocol assignment](https://www.iana.org/assignments/protocol-numbers/protocol-numbers.xhtml), which is typically `TCP`, `UDP`, or `ICMP`.

Example: `TCP`

Description: The version of [NetworkProtocol](#networkprotocol). When using it to distinguish between IP version, use the values `IPv4` and `IPv6`.
OriginalDescription: The version of [NetworkProtocol](#networkprotocol). When using it to distinguish between IP version, use the values `IPv4` and `IPv6`.

Description: The name or ID of the rule by which [DvcAction](#dvcaction) was decided upon.
OriginalDescription:
The name or ID of the rule by which [DvcAction](#dvcaction) was decided upon.

Example: `AnyAnyDrop`

Description: The number of the rule by which [DvcAction](#dvcaction) was decided upon.
OriginalDescription:
The number of the rule by which [DvcAction](#dvcaction) was decided upon.

Example: `23`

Description: The session identifier as reported by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription:
The session identifier as reported by the reporting device.

Example: `172\_12\_53\_32\_4322\_\_123\_64\_207\_1\_80`

Description:
Alias to [DstVlanId](#dstvlanid).

In many cases, the VLAN can't be determined as a source or a destination but is characterized as inner or outer. This alias to signifies that [DstVlanId](#dstvlanid) should be used when the VLAN is characterized as outer.
OriginalDescription:
Alias to [DstVlanId](#dstvlanid).

In many cases, the VLAN can't be determined as a source or a destination but is characterized as inner or outer. This alias to signifies that [DstVlanId](#dstvlanid) should be used when the VLAN is characterized as outer.

OriginalDescription:

Description: Either the value of [NetworkRuleName](#networkrulename) or the value of [NetworkRuleNumber](#networkrulenumber). If the value of [NetworkRuleNumber](#networkrulenumber) is used, the type should be converted to string.
OriginalDescription: Either the value of [NetworkRuleName](#networkrulename) or the value of [NetworkRuleNumber](#networkrulenumber). If the value of [NetworkRuleNumber](#networkrulenumber) is used, the type should be converted to string.

OriginalDescription: Alias to [NetworkSessionId](#networksessionid).

A unique identifier of the source device.

This field might alias the [SrcDvcId](#srcdvcid), [SrcHostname](#srchostname), or [SrcIpAddr](#srcipaddr) fields.
OriginalDescription:
A unique identifier of the source device.

This field might alias the [SrcDvcId](#srcdvcid), [SrcHostname](#srchostname), or [SrcIpAddr](#srcipaddr) fields.

Example: `192.168.12.1`

Description: The ID of the source application, as reported by the reporting device. If [SrcAppType](#srcapptype) is `Process`, `SrcAppId` and `SrcProcessId` should have the same value.
OriginalDescription:
The ID of the source application, as reported by the reporting device. If [SrcAppType](#srcapptype) is `Process`, `SrcAppId` and `SrcProcessId` should have the same value.

This field is mandatory if [SrcAppName](#srcappname) or [SrcAppId](#srcappid) are used.
OriginalDescription:

This field is mandatory if [SrcAppName](#srcappname) or [SrcAppId](#srcappid) are used.

OriginalDescription:
The number of bytes sent from the source to the destination for the connection or session. If the event is aggregated, **SrcBytes** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.

OriginalDescription: A descriptive text associated with the device. For example: `Primary Domain Controller`.

OriginalDescription: The type of the source device. For a list of allowed values and further information, refer to [DeviceType](normalization-about-schemas.md#devicetype) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

OriginalDescription:

**Note**: This field is required if [SrcDvcId](#srcdvcid) is used.

OriginalDescription: The cloud platform scope the device belongs to. **SrcDvcScope** map to a subscription ID on Azure and to an account ID on AWS.

OriginalDescription: The cloud platform scope ID the device belongs to. **SrcDvcScopeId** map to a subscription ID on Azure and to an account ID on AWS.

`46ad544b-eaf0-47ef-`

Description: The IP address from which the connection or session originated. This value is mandatory if **SrcHostname** is specified. If the session uses network address translation, `SrcIpAddr` is the publicly visible address, and not the original address of the source, which is stored in [SrcNatIpAddr](#srcnatipaddr)
OriginalDescription:
The IP address from which the connection or session originated. This value is mandatory if **SrcHostname** is specified. If the session uses network address translation, `SrcIpAddr` is the publicly visible address, and not the original address of the source, which is stored in [SrcNatIpAddr](#srcnatipaddr)

Example: `77.138.103.108`

OriginalDescription:
The MAC address of the network interface from which the connection or session originated.

Example: `06:10:9f:eb:8f:14`

Description:
The **SrcNatIpAddr** represents either of:
- The original address of the source device if network address translation was used.
- The IP address used by the intermediary device for communication with the destination.
OriginalDescription:
The **SrcNatIpAddr** represents either of:
- The original address of the source device if network address translation was used.
- The IP address used by the intermediary device for communication with the destination.

Example: `4.3.2.1`

OriginalDescription:
If reported by an intermediary NAT device, the port used by the NAT device for communication with the destination.

Example: `345`

Description: The original destination user type, if provided by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription: The original destination user type, if provided by the reporting device.

Description: The number of packets sent from the source to the destination for the connection or session. The meaning of a packet is defined by the reporting device. If the event is aggregated, **SrcPackets** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.
OriginalDescription:
The number of packets sent from the source to the destination for the connection or session. The meaning of a packet is defined by the reporting device. If the event is aggregated, **SrcPackets** should be the sum over all aggregated sessions.

OriginalDescription:
The IP port from which the connection originated. Might not be relevant for a session comprising multiple connections.

OriginalDescription:

Example: `EF3BD0BD-2B74-60C5-AF5C-010000001E00`

Description: The process ID (PID) of the process that initiated the network session.
Note:
The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows and Linux this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows or Linux machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.
OriginalDescription:
The process ID (PID) of the process that initiated the network session.

Example: `48610176`

**Note**: The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows and Linux this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows or Linux machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.

Description: The file name of the process that initiated the network session. This name is typically considered to be the process name.
OriginalDescription:
The file name of the process that initiated the network session. This name is typically considered to be the process name.

Example: `C:\Windows\explorer.exe`

OriginalDescription:

OriginalDescription: The type of the ID stored in the [SrcUserId](#srcuserid) field. For a list of allowed values and further information, refer to [UserIdType](normalization-entity-user.md#useridtype) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

OriginalDescription: The scope, such as Microsoft Entra tenant, in which [SrcUserId](#srcuserid) and [SrcUsername](#srcusername) are defined. or more information and list of allowed values, see [UserScope](normalization-entity-user.md#userscope) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

Description: The scope ID, such as Microsoft Entra Directory ID, in which [SrcUserId](#srcuserid) and [SrcUsername](#srcusername) are defined. for more information and list of allowed values, see [UserScopeId](normalization-entity-user.md#userscopeid) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).
OriginalDescription: The scope ID, such as Microsoft Entra Directory ID, in which [SrcUserId](#srcuserid) and [SrcUsername](#srcusername) are defined. for more information and list of allowed values, see [UserScopeId](normalization-entity-user.md#userscopeid) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

Description: The type of source user. For a list of allowed values and further information, refer to [UserType](normalization-entity-user.md#usertype) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).
Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Store the original value in the [SrcOriginalUserType](#srcoriginalusertype) field.
OriginalDescription:

Description:
The source username, including domain information when available. For the supported format for different ID types, refer to [the User entity](normalization-entity-user.md). Use the simple form only if domain information isn't available.

Store the Username type in the [SrcUsernameType](#srcusernametype) field. If other username formats are available, store them in the fields `SrcUsername`.

OriginalDescription:

Description: The network zone of the source, as defined by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription:
The network zone of the source, as defined by the reporting device.

Example: `Internet`

Description: The TCP ACK Flag reported. The acknowledgment flag is used to acknowledge the successful receipt of a packet. As we can see from the diagram above, the receiver sends an ACK and a SYN in the second step of the three way handshake process to tell the sender that it received its initial packet.
OriginalDescription: The TCP ACK Flag reported. The acknowledgment flag is used to acknowledge the successful receipt of a packet. As we can see from the diagram above, the receiver sends an ACK and a SYN in the second step of the three way handshake process to tell the sender that it received its initial packet.

Description: The TCP CWR Flag reported. The congestion window reduced flag is used by the sending host to indicate it received a packet with the ECE flag set. See [RFC 3168](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3168) for more details.
OriginalDescription: The TCP CWR Flag reported. The congestion window reduced flag is used by the sending host to indicate it received a packet with the ECE flag set. See [RFC 3168](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3168) for more details.

Description: The TCP ECE Flag reported. This flag is responsible for indicating if the TCP peer is [ECN capable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_Congestion_Notification). See [RFC 3168](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3168) for more details.
OriginalDescription: The TCP ECE Flag reported. This flag is responsible for indicating if the TCP peer is [ECN capable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_Congestion_Notification). See [RFC 3168](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3168) for more details.

Description: The TCP FIN Flag reported. The finished flag means there is no more data from the sender. Therefore, it is used in the last packet sent from the sender.
OriginalDescription: The TCP FIN Flag reported. The finished flag means there is no more data from the sender. Therefore, it is used in the last packet sent from the sender.

Description: The TCP NS Flag reported. The nonce sum flag is still an experimental flag used to help protect against accidental malicious concealment of packets from the sender. See [RFC 3540](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3540) for more details
OriginalDescription: The TCP NS Flag reported. The nonce sum flag is still an experimental flag used to help protect against accidental malicious concealment of packets from the sender. See [RFC 3540](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3540) for more details

Description: The TCP PSH Flag reported. The push flag is similar to the URG flag and tells the receiver to process these packets as they are received instead of buffering them.
OriginalDescription: The TCP PSH Flag reported. The push flag is similar to the URG flag and tells the receiver to process these packets as they are received instead of buffering them.

Description: The TCP RST Flag reported. The reset flag gets sent from the receiver to the sender when a packet is sent to a particular host that was not expecting it.
OriginalDescription: The TCP RST Flag reported. The reset flag gets sent from the receiver to the sender when a packet is sent to a particular host that was not expecting it.

Description: The TCP SYN Flag reported. The synchronization flag is used as a first step in establishing a three way handshake between two hosts. Only the first packet from both the sender and receiver should have this flag set.
OriginalDescription: The TCP SYN Flag reported. The synchronization flag is used as a first step in establishing a three way handshake between two hosts. Only the first packet from both the sender and receiver should have this flag set.

Description: The TCP URG Flag reported. The urgent flag is used to notify the receiver to process the urgent packets before processing all other packets. The receiver will be notified when all known urgent data has been received. See [RFC 6093](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6093) for more details.
OriginalDescription: The TCP URG Flag reported. The urgent flag is used to notify the receiver to process the urgent packets before processing all other packets. The receiver will be notified when all known urgent data has been received. See [RFC 6093](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6093) for more details.

Description: The category of the threat or malware identified in the network session.
OriginalDescription:
The category of the threat or malware identified in the network session.

Example: `Trojan`

Description: The confidence level of the threat identified, normalized to a value between 0 and a 100.
OriginalDescription: The confidence level of the threat identified, normalized to a value between 0 and a 100.

Description: The field for which a threat was identified. The value is either `SrcIpAddr` or `DstIpAddr`.
OriginalDescription: The field for which a threat was identified. The value is either `SrcIpAddr` or `DstIpAddr`.

Description: The first time the IP address or domain were identified as a threat.
OriginalDescription: The first time the IP address or domain were identified as a threat.

Description: The ID of the threat or malware identified in the network session.
OriginalDescription:
The ID of the threat or malware identified in the network session.

Example: `Tr.124`

Description: An IP address for which a threat was identified. The field [ThreatField](#threatfield) contains the name of the field **ThreatIpAddr** represents.
OriginalDescription: An IP address for which a threat was identified. The field [ThreatField](#threatfield) contains the name of the field **ThreatIpAddr** represents.

Description: True if the threat identified is considered an active threat.
OriginalDescription: True if the threat identified is considered an active threat.

Description: The last time the IP address or domain were identified as a threat.
OriginalDescription: The last time the IP address or domain were identified as a threat.

Description: The name of the threat or malware identified in the network session.
OriginalDescription:
The name of the threat or malware identified in the network session.

Example: `EICAR Test File`

Description: The original confidence level of the threat identified, as reported by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription: The original confidence level of the threat identified, as reported by the reporting device.

Description: The risk level as reported by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription: The risk level as reported by the reporting device.

Description: The risk level associated with the session. The level should be a number between **0** and **100**.
Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using a different scale, which should be normalized to this scale. The original value should be stored in [ThreatRiskLevelOriginal](#threatoriginalriskleveloriginal).
OriginalDescription:
The risk level associated with the session. The level should be a number between **0** and **100**.

**Note**: The value might be provided in the source record by using a different scale, which should be normalized to this scale. The original value should be stored in [ThreatRiskLevelOriginal](#threatoriginalriskleveloriginal).

Description: The time the event was generated by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription: The time the event was generated by the reporting device.

Description:
The original table from which the record was fetched. This field is useful when the same event can be received through multiple channels to different tables, and have the same [EventVendor](#eventvendor) and [EventProduct](#eventproduct) values.

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.
OriginalDescription:
The original table from which the record was fetched. This field is useful when the same event can be received through multiple channels to different tables, and have the same [EventVendor](#eventvendor) and [EventProduct](#eventproduct) values.

For example, a Sysmon event can be collected either to the `Event` table or to the `WindowsEvent` table.

OriginalDescription: Alias to [DstUsername](#dstusername).

OriginalDescription: The date and time when the acting process was started.

OriginalDescription:
The product name from the version information in the acting process image file.

The product version from the version information of the acting process image file.

OriginalDescription:
The file name part of the `ActingProcessName`, without folder information.

Example: `explorer.exe`

OriginalDescription:
A generated unique identifier (GUID) of the acting process. Enables identifying the process across systems.

Example: `EF3BD0BD-2B74-60C5-AF5C-010000001E00`

Description: The Import Hash of all the library DLLs that are used by the acting process.
OriginalDescription: The Import Hash of all the library DLLs that are used by the acting process.

Description: The process ID (PID) of the acting process.
Note:
The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows and Linux this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows or Linux machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.
OriginalDescription:
The process ID (PID) of the acting process.

Example: `48610176`

**Note**: The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows and Linux this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows or Linux machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.

Description: The memory address in which the responsible acting process is stored.
OriginalDescription: The memory address in which the responsible acting process is stored.

Description:
Every process has an integrity level that is represented in its token. Integrity levels determine the process level of protection or access.

Windows defines the following integrity levels: **low**, **medium**, **high**, and **system**. Standard users receive a **medium** integrity level and elevated users receive a **high** integrity level.

For more information, see [Mandatory Integrity Control - Win32 apps](/windows/win32/secauthz/mandatory-integrity-control).
OriginalDescription:
Every process has an integrity level that is represented in its token. Integrity levels determine the process level of protection or access.

Windows defines the following integrity levels: **low**, **medium**, **high**, and **system**. Standard users receive a **medium** integrity level and elevated users receive a **high** integrity level.

For more information, see [Mandatory Integrity Control - Win32 apps](/windows/win32/secauthz/mandatory-integrity-control).

Description: An indication of whether the acting process is in hidden mode.
OriginalDescription: An indication of whether the acting process is in hidden mode.

Description: The MD5 hash of the acting process image file.
OriginalDescription:
The MD5 hash of the acting process image file.

Example: `75a599802f1fa166cdadb360960b1dd0`

Description: The name of the acting process. This name is commonly derived from the image or executable file that's used to define the initial code and data that's mapped into the process' virtual address space.
OriginalDescription:
The name of the acting process. This name is commonly derived from the image or executable file that's used to define the initial code and data that's mapped into the process' virtual address space.

Example: `C:\Windows\explorer.exe`

Description: The SHA-1 hash of the acting process image file.
OriginalDescription:
The SHA-1 hash of the acting process image file.

Example: `d55c5a4df19b46db8c54c801c4665d3338acdab0`

OriginalDescription:
The SHA-256 hash of the acting process image file.

Example:
`e81bb824c4a09a811af17deae22f22dd`
`2e1ec8cbb00b22629d2899f7c68da274`

Description: The SHA-512 hash of the acting process image file.
OriginalDescription: The SHA-512 hash of the acting process image file.

Description: A token indicating the presence or absence of User Access Control (UAC) privilege elevation applied to the acting process.
OriginalDescription:
A token indicating the presence or absence of User Access Control (UAC) privilege elevation applied to the acting process.

Example: `None`

Description: The original destination user type, if provided by the reporting device.
OriginalDescription: The original destination user type, if provided by the reporting device.

Description: The scope, such as Microsoft Entra tenant, in which [ActorUserId](#actoruserid) and [ActorUsername](#actorusername) are defined. or more information and list of allowed values, see [UserScope](normalization-entity-user.md#userscope) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).
OriginalDescription: The scope, such as Microsoft Entra tenant, in which [ActorUserId](#actoruserid) and [ActorUsername](#actorusername) are defined. or more information and list of allowed values, see [UserScope](normalization-entity-user.md#userscope) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

Description: The scope ID, such as Microsoft Entra Directory ID, in which [ActorUserId](#actoruserid) and [ActorUsername](#actorusername) are defined. or more information and list of allowed values, see [UserScopeId](normalization-entity-user.md#userscopeid) in the [Schema Overview article](normalization-about-schemas.md).

Description: The unique ID of the login session of the Actor.
Note:
The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.
OriginalDescription:
The unique ID of the login session of the Actor.

Example: `999`

**Note**: The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.

Description: A machine-readable, alphanumeric, unique representation of the Actor. For the supported format for different ID types, refer to [the User entity](normalization-entity-user.md).
OriginalDescription:

Description:
The Actor username, including domain information when available. For the supported format for different ID types, refer to [the User entity](normalization-entity-user.md). Use the simple form only if domain information isn't available.

Store the Username type in the [ActorUsernameType](#actorusernametype) field. If other username formats are available, store them in the fields `ActorUsername`.
OriginalDescription:
The Actor username, including domain information when available. For the supported format for different ID types, refer to [the User entity](normalization-entity-user.md). Use the simple form only if domain information isn't available.

Store the Username type in the [ActorUsernameType](#actorusernametype) field. If other username formats are available, store them in the fields `ActorUsername`.

OriginalDescription:

OriginalDescription:

This value is used when the source supports aggregation, and a single record might represent multiple events.

OriginalDescription: The time in which the event ended. If the source supports aggregation and the record represents multiple events, the time that the last event was generated. If not provided by the source record, this field aliases the [TimeGenerated](#timegenerated) field.

OriginalDescription: The original result details provided by the source. This value is used to derive [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails), which should have only one of the values documented for each schema.

Description: The unique ID of the login session of the Actor.
Note:
The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.
OriginalDescription:
The unique ID of the login session of the Actor.

Example: `999`

**Note**: The type is defined as *string* to support varying systems, but on Windows this value must be numeric.

If you are using a Windows machine and used a different type, make sure to convert the values. For example, if you used a hexadecimal value, convert it to a decimal value.

Description:
A machine-readable, alphanumeric, unique representation of the Actor.

Supported formats and types include:
- **SID** (Windows): `S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-500`
- **UID** (Linux): `4578`
- **AADID** (Microsoft Entra ID): `9267d02c-5f76-40a9-a9eb-b686f3ca47aa`
- **OktaId**: `00urjk4znu3BcncfY0h7`
- **AWSId**: `72643944673`

Store the ID type in the [ActorUserIdType](#actoruseridtype) field. If other IDs are available, we recommend that you normalize the field names to **ActorUserSid**, **ActorUserUid**, **ActorUserAadId**, **ActorUserOktaId**, and **ActorAwsId**, respectively. For more information, see [The User entity](normalization-entity-user.md).
OriginalDescription:
A machine-readable, alphanumeric, unique representation of the Actor.

Supported formats and types include:

- **UID** (Linux): `4578`
- **AADID** (Microsoft Entra ID): `9267d02c-5f76-40a9-a9eb-b686f3ca47aa`
- **OktaId**: `00urjk4znu3BcncfY0h7`
- **AWSId**: `72643944673`

Store the ID type in the [ActorUserIdType](#actoruseridtype) field. If other IDs are available, we recommend that you normalize the field names to **ActorUserSid**, **ActorUserUid**, **ActorUserAadId**, **ActorUserOktaId**, and **ActorAwsId**, respectively. For more information, see [The User entity](normalization-entity-user.md).

Example: S-1-12

- `Regular`
- `Machine`
- `Admin`
- `System`
- `Application`

Note: The value might be provided in the source record by using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. Store the original value in the [ActorOriginalUserType](#actororiginalusertype) field.

Description:
The Actor username, including domain information when available.

Use one of the following formats and in the following order of priority:
- **Upn/Email**: `johndow@contoso.com`
- **Windows**: `Contoso\johndow`
- **DN**: `CN=Jeff Smith,OU=Sales,DC=Fabrikam,DC=COM`
- **Simple**: `johndow`. Use the Simple form only if domain information isn't available.

Store the Username type in the [ActorUsernameType](#actorusernametype) field. If other IDs are available, we recommend that you normalize the field names to **ActorUserUpn**, **ActorUserWindows**, and **ActorUserDn**.

For more information, see [The User entity](normalization-entity-user.md).
OriginalDescription:
The Actor username, including domain information when available.

Use one of the following formats and in the following order of priority:
- **Upn/Email**: `johndow@contoso.com`
- **Windows**: `Contoso\johndow`
- **DN**: `CN=Jeff Smith,OU=Sales,DC=Fabrikam,DC=COM`
- **Simple**: `johndow`. Use the Simple form only if domain information isn't available.

Store the Username type in the [ActorUsernameType](#actorusernametype) field. If other IDs are available, we recommend that you normalize the field names to **ActorUserUpn**, **ActorUserWindows**, and **ActorUserDn**.

For more information, see [The User entity](normalization-entity-user.md).

Example: `AlbertE`

Description: Specifies the type of the username stored in the [ActorUsername](#actorusername) field. Supported values are `UPN`, `Windows`, `DN`, and `Simple`. For more information, see [The User entity](normalization-entity-user.md).

Description:
Describes the event result, normalized to one of the following values:
- `Success`
- `Partial`
- `Failure`
- `NA` (not applicable)

For an HTTP session, `Success` is defined as a status code lower than `400`, and `Failure` is defined as a status code higher than `400`. For a list of HTTP status codes, refer to [W3 Org](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html).

The source may provide only a value for the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which must be analyzed to get the **EventResult** value.
OriginalDescription:
Describes the event result, normalized to one of the following values:
- `Success`
- `Partial`
- `Failure`
- `NA` (not applicable)

For an HTTP session, `Success` is defined as a status code lower than `400`, and `Failure` is defined as a status code higher than `400`. For a list of HTTP status codes, refer to [W3 Org](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html).

The source may provide only a value for the [EventResultDetails](#eventresultdetails) field, which must be analyzed to get the **EventResult** value.

Description: The HTTP status code as defined by [The World Wide Web Consortium](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/HTRESP.html)
Note: The value may be provided in the source record using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. The original value should be stored in the **EventOriginalResultDetails** field.
OriginalDescription:
The HTTP status code as defined by [The World Wide Web Consortium](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/HTRESP.html)

**Note**: The value may be provided in the source record using different terms, which should be normalized to these values. The original value should be stored in the **EventOriginalResultDetails** field.
